pageData.text: Maintaining the water-solute balance of blood and other body fluids is an important part of homeostasis. As the principle organs of the urinary system, the <button class='glossary-text'>kidneys</button> maintain this balance by filtering the blood and producing <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button>. In this investigation, you will explore kidney function and analyze the characteristics of urine.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking pictures
Clear, resealable plastic bags (optional)
Timer or mobile device with a timer function
Permanent marker
Approximately 1 tsp ground coffee (not instant)
Paper towels
Ruler (optional)
Access to a toilet
Access to a sink and tap water
Piece of white paper
Spoon or stirrer

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: Measuring Specific Gravity Using a Hydrometer - 10 minutes
Activity 2: Assessing the Appearance and Odor of Real Urine(optional) - 10 minutes
Activity 3: Determining Urine Composition - 10 minutes
Activity 4: Modeling Urine Production - 60 minutes

Preparation - 5 minutes
Activity 1: Measuring Specific Gravity Using a Hydrometer - 10 minutes

pageData.text: Note for instructors: This investigation offers students the opportunity to test their own . They may provide their test results as part of the assessment. This is confidential medical information that should not be stored or shared with your health services group or the rest of the class.

Note for students: If you opt to test your own urine, please be aware that the urine tests performed in this investigation are for educational purposes and should not be used for diagnosis of medical conditions. If your results seem unusual, seek advice from a medical professional.

text: List the main structures of the <button class='glossary-text'>kidney</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>nephron</button>, and relate their respective roles in <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button> production.
Explain and model the processes of urine production.
Describe the expected properties and constituents of urine, and recognize notable variations and their possible causes.
Analyze urine for appearance, odor, <button class='glossary-text'>specific gravity</button>, and composition.

pageData.text: “Asparagus pee” is a well-reported phenomenon that occurs after many people eat asparagus. The distinctive odor smells like sulfur or cooked cabbage and is a result of the way the body breaks down compounds in asparagus, such as asparagusic acid. Not everyone breaks down these compounds the same way and some people don’t experience the phenomenon at all. Asparagus isn’t the only thing that can make smell strange. Eating garlic and onions can also give urine an unpleasant odor.Sometimes strange-smelling urine can be a sign of a disease. An ammonia-like smell and dark urine color are associated with severe dehydration. A rare, life-threatening genetic disease called maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) can make urine and ear wax smell like maple syrup. This happens because people with MSUD are unable to break down certain amino acids which are then expelled through urination. Historically, diabetes was diagnosed by tasting a patient’s urine. Sweet-tasting urine indicated a positive test for diabetes because some of the excess glucose in the patient’s bloodstream would be filtered out into the urine.

pageData.desc: Two plastic collection cups filled with urine samples.
pageData.altText: Two plastic collection cups filled with urine samples.

pageData.text: The urinary system filters extra water and waste products from the blood to help maintain proper fluid balance inside the body. An elaborate system of tubes and tubules intertwines with arteries and veins within the <button class='glossary-text'>kidneys</button> to allow for maximum excretion of waste products, such as various salts and proteins. The ureters carry this waste to the bladder, where it is stored until excretion.

pageData.subTitle: Urinary System
pageData.text: Ureters are long, thin tubes that carry from the (where it is produced) to the bladder.The bladder is a muscular sac that stores urine.The urethra is a narrow tube connected to the bladder that removes urine from the body.

labelInfo.labelName: Abdominal aorta (main artery from heart) carries blood from heart to kidneys
Inferior vena cava (main vein to heart) carries filtered blood from kidneys to body

pageData.subTitle: Kidneys
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>kidneys</button> are found in the upper abdomen on each side of the spine. These fist-size organs filter waste products out of the bloodstream and produce <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button>.

pageData.subTitle: Nephrons
pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Nephrons</button> contain a network of tubes, veins, and arteries that intertwine to exchange salts, wastes, and fluids to remove them from the bloodstream.

pageData.subTitle: Glomerulus
pageData.text: A <button class='glossary-text'>glomerulus</button> is a small, round pocket within the kidneys that uses concentration gradients to remove nitrogenous waste and salts from the blood vessels that pass through it.

The water-solute balance of blood and other fluids is vital to homeostasis, the dynamically stable internal state of the body. The primary function of the urinary system is <button class='glossary-text'>osmoregulation</button>—the control of solutes, mostly ions, in blood and other body fluids. <button class='glossary-text'>Urine</button>, the fluid formed by the <button class='glossary-text'>kidneys</button>, is 95% water and 5% solutes, including nitrogenous wastes. <button class='glossary-text'>Urea</button> is the main nitrogenous waste in the urine of humans and other mammals. It is produced when amino acids are broken down. Other nitrogenous wastes are <button class='glossary-text'>uric acid</button>—produced when purines, a key component of nucleic acids, are degraded—and <button class='glossary-text'>creatinine</button>, released when creatine phosphate is used in skeletal muscle.
There are three processes involved in urine production:

text: <button class='glossary-text'>Filtration</button>—water and solutes are filtered from the blood, yielding a fluid called <button class='glossary-text'>filtrate</button>.
<button class='glossary-text'>Reabsorption</button>—water and solutes are returned to the blood, and filtrate becomes urine.
<button class='glossary-text'>Secretion</button>—specific substances are removed from the blood.

pageData.subTitle: The Kidneys
pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>kidneys</button> are the principle organs of the urinary system. These two bean-shaped organs are responsible for the three processes involved in <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button> production. Each kidney has an outer layer, called the <button class='glossary-text'>cortex</button>, and an inner layer, the <button class='glossary-text'>medulla</button> (see Figure 1). The cortex contains the blood-filtering structures of the kidney. The medulla contains the structures responsible for maintaining the solute-water balance of the blood.</button>

Blood flows into each kidney through the renal artery (see Figure 1). The renal artery splits into branches called the segmental arteries. These branch further into interlobar arteries. The interlobar arteries branch again, forming the arcuate arteries that run between the cortex and medulla. These feed into <button class='glossary-text'>afferent arterioles</button>, from which blood enters a capillary network, the <button class='glossary-text'>glomerulus</button> of the <button class='glossary-text'>nephron</button>.

The nephron (see Figure 1) is the functional unit of the kidney. Each kidney contains over a million nephrons. The nephrons are responsible for blood and urine production. Each nephron is made up of two structures: the glomerulus and a . The glomerulus is an aggregation of capillaries surrounded by the (Bowman’s capsule); together, the glomerulus and its capsule are called the . The role of the glomerular capsule is to filter out large molecules and cellular material present in the blood. Renal corpuscles reside in the cortex of the kidney.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Diagrams of the kidney showing its major structures and the nephron, depicting its major structures and the direction of blood flow
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagrams of the kidney showing its major structures and the nephron, depicting its major structures and the direction of blood flow

pageData.text: Blood leaves the <button class='glossary-text'>glomerulus</button> through the <button class='glossary-text'>efferent arteriole</button>. The diameter of the <button class='glossary-text'>afferent arteriole</button> is larger than that of the efferent arteriole, creating pressure in the capillaries of the glomerulus. This pressure forces water, salts, glucose, <button class='glossary-text'>urea</button>, amino acids, and waste products out of the blood capillaries and into the <button class='glossary-text'>glomerular capsule</button>. Large particles and molecules—including plasma proteins, blood cells, and platelets—remain in the capillaries because they are too large to pass through the capillary walls; these pass out of the glomerulus via the efferent arteriole. The fluid remaining in the capsule, called <button class='glossary-text'>filtrate</button>, will eventually become <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button>.

The filtrate passes into the first segment of the <button class='glossary-text'>renal tubule</button>, the <button class='glossary-text'>proximal convoluted tubule</button>. Specialized cells in the proximal convoluted tubule selectively reabsorb salts and nutrients from the filtrate and transfer them into the adjacent <button class='glossary-text'>peritubular capillaries</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Secretion</button> in the proximal convoluted tubule adds hydrogen ions, ammonium, and certain drugs to the filtrate. The <button class='glossary-text'>descending limb</button> of the <button class='glossary-text'>nephron</button> loop, carrying the filtrate, runs down into the <button class='glossary-text'>medulla</button> region of the <button class='glossary-text'>kidney</button>. Interestingly, the blood in the peritubular capillaries flows in a direction opposite that of the filtrate in the tubule. The solute concentration in the capillaries and surrounding fluid is higher than in the filtrate, so there is a concentration gradient that causes water to flow out of the filtrate and into the blood within the peritubular capillaries. This gradually concentrates the filtrate. The cells lining the descending limb are permeable to water but not to urea or ions, preventing these substances from moving out of the descending limb and being reabsorbed into the blood as the concentration of the filtrate increases.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Diagrams of the kidney showing its major structures and the nephron, depicting its major structures and the direction of blood flow
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagrams of the kidney showing its major structures and the nephron, depicting its major structures and the direction of blood flow

pageData.text: The <button class='glossary-text'>descending limb</button> makes a hairpin turn, reversing its orientation at the <button class='glossary-text'>loop of the nephron (loop of Henle)</button> and becoming the <button class='glossary-text'>ascending limb</button> of the <button class='glossary-text'>nephron</button> loop, which reenters the <button class='glossary-text'>cortex</button>. Cells in this limb are impermeable to water, preventing osmosis from diluting the <button class='glossary-text'>filtrate</button>, but they are permeable to ions. Some of these move out of the filtrate in response to the concentration gradient established by the low external solute concentration. <button class='glossary-text'>Secretion</button> in the ascending limb adds <button class='glossary-text'>urea</button> to the filtrate. Toward the upper region of the ascending limb, selected ions are actively transported out of the filtrate. The filtrate moves from the ascending limb into the <button class='glossary-text'>distal convoluted tubule</button>, where more water is recovered and the solute concentrations, particularly of ions, are further adjusted.

The filtrate passes from the distal convoluted tubule into the <button class='glossary-text'>collecting duct</button>, which descends into the <button class='glossary-text'>medulla</button>. Since the medulla has a high solute concentration, more water is lost from the filtrate to the surrounding tissue via osmosis. A powerful hormone, the antidiuretic hormone (ADH), stimulates <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button> concentration by the collecting ducts, and the processes of <button class='glossary-text'>reabsorption</button> and secretion result in final adjustments to the content of the urine. Several collecting ducts converge to direct urine toward the ureter, which conveys urine from the <button class='glossary-text'>kidney</button> to the urinary bladder.

The blood in the <button class='glossary-text'>peritubular capillaries</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>efferent arteriole</button> flows into the arcuate veins and, from there, into the interlobar veins. The interlobar veins converge at the renal vein, which exits the kidney.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Diagrams of the kidney showing its major structures and the nephron, depicting its major structures and the direction of blood flow
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagrams of the kidney showing its major structures and the nephron, depicting its major structures and the direction of blood flow

pageData.question: What is the functional unit of the kidney?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The nephron is the functional unit of the kidney.

pageData.question: Each nephron is made up of two structures: the glomerulus and a renal tubule. What is the role of the glomerular capsule?

options.text: filter out large molecules and cellular material present in the blood
filter out carbohydrates that are present in the blood
prevent substances from moving to the filtrate as its concentration increases
contain the structures responsible for maintaining the solute-water balance of the blood

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The role of the glomerular capsule is to filter out large molecules and cellular material present in the blood.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Each kidney contains over a million nephrons. Nephrons are responsible for blood filtration and urine production. Each nephron is made up of two structures: the glomerulus and a renal tubule. The glomerulus is an aggregation of capillaries surrounded by the glomerular capsule (Bowman’s capsule); together, the glomerulus and its capsule are called the renal corpuscle. Blood leaves the glomerulus through the efferent arteriole. The diameter of the afferent arteriole is larger than that of the efferent arteriole, creating pressure in the capillaries of the glomerulus. This pressure forces water, salts, glucose, urea, amino acids, and waste products out of the blood capillaries and into the glomerular capsule. Large particles and molecules—including plasma proteins, blood cells, and platelets—remain in the capillaries because they are too large to pass through the capillary walls; these pass out of the glomerulus via the efferent arteriole.

pageData.subTitle: Characteristics of Urine
pageData.text: Because <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button> production is so crucial to the maintenance of homeostasis, the analysis of urine, or <button class='glossary-text'>urinalysis</button>, is a common part of health assessment. A urine sample has four interrelated characteristics: appearance, odor, <button class='glossary-text'>specific gravity</button>, and composition. These characteristics may be affected by fluid intake, diet, physical activity, certain medications, and many different health conditions.</button>

Appearance is the most immediately noticeable characteristic of a urine specimen. Urine is normally a clear liquid. <button class='glossary-text'>Turbidity</button> (cloudiness) may suggest a urinary tract infection (UTI). The yellow color typical of urine is due to the presence of a pigment called urochrome, produced from the breakdown of hemoglobin. The color of normal urine may vary depending on concentration, from almost colorless to pale yellow to dark amber. Unusual urine color can have a variety of causes. Pink or red urine may be caused by the presence of blood, known as <button class='glossary-text'>hematuria</button>, which may indicate potentially serious disorders of the blood and/or urinary system. However, foods such as beets and rhubarb can also turn urine red or pink. Vitamin B<sub class='bodySubscript'>12</sub> supplements can result in bright yellow-green urine. Several drugs can also alter urine color.

Urine may be subjected to microscopic examination to obtain more details. For example, a turbid sample may be examined to see if bacteria and <button class='glossary-text'>leukocytes</button> (white blood cells) are present. If they are, this indicates a bacterial UTI. Certain solutes common to urine may appear in crystalline form. Although it is not unusual or concerning to have a few crystals in the urine, numerous crystals, especially of particular kinds, may require additional investigation.

Numerous <button class='glossary-text'>uric acid</button> crystals may indicate <button class='glossary-text'>gout</button>, a type of arthritis involving the sudden onset of pain and swelling in the joints, particularly the base of the big toe. Large amounts of uric acid crystals may also herald the development of uric acid <button class='glossary-text'>kidney stones</button>. Kidney stones, known as renal calculi, are solid masses of crystals that may be detected in <button class='glossary-text'>kidneys</button>, ureters, or the bladder. They can be extremely painful. Small stones may be passed through the urinary tract without medical intervention. However, larger kidney stones become dangerous if they block the drainage of urine from a kidney. Such kidney stones may need to be broken apart with shock waves or even surgically removed.

Uric acid kidney stones are just one variety. <button class='glossary-text'>Kidney stones</button> may also be composed of calcium, struvite, or other substances. Calcium oxalate stones are the most common type of kidney stones in humans, although other calcium compounds, such as calcium phosphate, also occur. Oxalate is a naturally occurring, calcium-binding compound found in both plants and animals. People prone to forming calcium oxalate kidney stones, such as those with abundant calcium oxalate crystals in their <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button>, are advised to reduce the amount of oxalate in their diets.

Struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) kidney stones are common in individuals with UTIs caused by bacteria that break down <button class='glossary-text'>urea</button> and produce ammonia. Treatment of this type of kidney stone involves treatment of the UTI.

Odor should be faint in most normal, fresh urine samples. A strong, unpleasant odor is suggestive of bacteria and a possible UTI. Certain drugs, such as penicillin, and foods, including asparagus, lend distinctive odors to urine.

feedbackData.text: Pink or red urine may be caused by the presence of blood (hematuria). Foods such as beets and rhubarb can also turn urine red or pink.

pageData.question: What misdiagnosis could occur if a person consumed large amounts of asparagus?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Many people who eat asparagus report that their urine has a strong order. A strong unpleasant odor is suggestive of bacteria and a possible urinary tract infection (UTI).

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A urine sample has four interrelated characteristics: appearance, odor, specific gravity, and composition. These characteristics may be affected by fluid intake, diet, physical activity, certain medications, and many different health conditions. Turbidity (cloudiness) may suggest a urinary tract infection (UTI). Pink or red urine may be caused by the presence of blood, known as hematuria, which may indicate potentially serious disorders of the blood and/or urinary system. Odor should be faint in most normal, fresh urine samples. A strong, unpleasant odor is suggestive of bacteria and a possible UTI. Certain drugs, such as penicillin, and foods, including asparagus, lend distinctive odors to urine.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A urine sample has four interrelated characteristics: appearance, odor, specific gravity, and composition. These characteristics may be affected by fluid intake, diet, physical activity, certain medications, and many different health conditions. Turbidity (cloudiness) may suggest a urinary tract infection (UTI). Pink or red urine may be caused by the presence of blood, known as hematuria, which may indicate potentially serious disorders of the blood and/or urinary system. Odor should be faint in most normal, fresh urine samples. A strong, unpleasant odor is suggestive of bacteria and a possible UTI. Certain drugs, such as penicillin, and foods, including asparagus, lend distinctive odors to urine.

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Specific gravity</button> is a gauge of how concentrated or dilute a <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button> sample is. It is traditionally determined using a simple device called a <button class='glossary-text'>hydrometer</button>. Specific gravity is defined as the ratio of the density of a fluid to that of a reference fluid. To determine the specific gravity of a urine sample, the reference used is water, which has a specific gravity of 1. The solute content of a urine sample will cause its specific gravity to differ from that of pure water. A typical specific gravity range for urine is 1.002-1.030. Low specific gravity (1.001-1.003) may indicate a condition known as <button class='glossary-text'>diabetes insipidus</button>. The hallmarks of this condition are polydipsia (intense thirst that is not relieved by fluid intake) and polyuria (the production of a large volume of dilute urine). Diabetes insipidus occurs when the <button class='glossary-text'>kidneys</button> are unable to concentrate the urine due to either an ADH deficiency or to an inability of the kidneys to respond to this hormone. Elevated specific gravity may indicate a variety of conditions, including dehydration (from perspiration, diarrhea, vomiting, etc.) and reduced blood flow to the kidney (as occurs with congestive heart failure).

Composition of <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button> encompasses the various solutes that may be present, including nitrogenous wastes and electrolytes. Composition is commonly determined using urine test strips (see Figure 2, and <button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button>), which are immersed in a urine sample and then examined for color changes. Some test strips are very simple and are used to determine the relative amount of a specific solute, such as glucose. Others allow multiple tests to simultaneously be carried out for several solutes and, in some cases, even for the presence of blood cells. The <button class='glossary-text'>urinalysis</button> test strips used in this investigation detect pH (acidity), glucose, ketones, <button class='glossary-text'>leukocytes</button>, nitrite, protein, and blood (especially hemoglobin from red blood cells).

On the pH scale, a value of 7 is neutral. Pure water has a pH of 7. Values greater than 7 are basic (alkaline), and those less than 7 are acidic. Urine has an average pH of approximately 6, although variations between 4.6 and 8.0 are not unusual. Diet can slightly raise or lower the pH of the urine. A mainly plant-based diet can raise the pH, while a diet rich in meat, fish, and/or cheese can lower the pH of urine. The pH of urine reflects the overall health of the body. Elevated urine pH may suggest a UTI, since some bacteria that grow in urine create ammonia, an alkaline substance. Lower pH may result from diabetic ketoacidosis.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: PH color strip chart, showing colors as listed in Table 1 to compare at 60 seconds for PH, glucose, ketones, leukocytes, nitrite, protein, and blood/hemoglobin: and at 120 seconds for leukocytes
pageData.altText: Figure 2: PH color strip chart, showing colors as listed in Table 1 to compare at 60 seconds for PH, glucose, ketones, leukocytes, nitrite, protein, and blood/hemoglobin: and at 120 seconds for leukocytes

pageData.text: Glucose in the , known as , results when glucose (“blood sugar”) is not reabsorbed during urine formation. This is usually due to , a disorder in which blood levels of glucose become so high that the glucose cannot all be reabsorbed and the excess ends up in the urine. Glucose is the preferred fuel that body cells use for energy. In a healthy individual, the pancreatic hormone enables cells to take up glucose. But in diabetes mellitus, glucose cannot enter the cells because either the pancreas doesn’t produce enough insulin or the body cells are not sensitive to it.

Ketones in the urine indicate that the body is using fat as a source of energy instead of glucose. Ketones are a product of fat metabolism. A small amount of ketones is not unusual in individuals who follow low-carbohydrate diets for weight reduction. However, diabetic ketoacidosis is a condition in people with diabetes mellitus in which the buildup of high concentrations of ketones causes the blood to become too acidic. Coma and even death may result.
<button class='glossary-text'>Leukocytes</button> in the urine are common when there is a UTI. Leukocytes are important in protecting the body from harmful microorganisms, such as bacteria.
Another indication of a UTI is nitrite in the urine. Just as some bacteria convert <button class='glossary-text'>urea</button> in urine to ammonia, some convert nitrates into nitrite.

Low levels of protein in the urine are not remarkable, especially after vigorous exercise. However, excess protein in the urine, known as <button class='glossary-text'>proteinuria</button>, can indicate a wide range of diseases, including diabetes mellitus, glomerulonephritis (inflammation of the glomerular <button class='glossary-text'>filtration</button> units of the <button class='glossary-text'>kidneys</button>), high blood pressure, and sickle cell anemia.

Blood in the urine, called <button class='glossary-text'>hematuria</button>, may be so abundant that it is visible to the unaided eye as red or brown urine, or the amount of blood may be so small that it shows up only under microscopic examination or use of a test strip. It may have many causes, such as a UTI; a <button class='glossary-text'>kidney stone</button>; glomerulonephritis; cancer; a kidney injury; or even taking certain drugs, including penicillin. Hemoglobin is the protein found in red blood cells that binds oxygen. Hemoglobin in the urine, hemoglobinuria, occurs when red blood cells burst open, or lyse. Urine may also contain a similar protein, myoglobin, found in cardiac and skeletal muscle tissues. If these tissues are damaged—for example, from a heart attack, from a crushing muscle injury, or even from overexertion of an individual in untrained physical condition—then myoglobin will appear in the urine, a condition called myoglobinuria.

pageData.question: What disorder can occur if the body is not able to reabsorb glucose?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Diabetes mellitus results when blood levels of glucose become so high that the glucose cannot all be reabsorbed.

pageData.question: What is the hormone that regulates glucose levels?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The pancreatic hormone insulin helps regulate glucose levels in the blood.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Glucose in the urine, known as glycosuria, results when glucose (“blood sugar”) is not reabsorbed during urine formation. This is usually due to diabetes mellitus, a disorder in which blood levels of glucose become so high that the glucose cannot all be reabsorbed, and the excess ends up in the urine. Glucose is the preferred fuel that body cells use for energy. In a healthy individual, the pancreatic hormone insulin enables cells to take up glucose. But in diabetes mellitus, glucose cannot enter the cells because either the pancreas doesn’t produce enough insulin, or the body cells are not sensitive to it.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for this investigation. As an optional preparation, you can collect your own urine sample. In Activity 1, you will measure the specific gravity of both simulated urine samples using the hydrometer. Repeat this step for your own urine sample, if applicable. Activity 2 is only for those testing their own urine. You will determine the color, clarity, and odor strength of your own urine. In Activity 3, you will test both simulated urine samples with urinalysis test strips and record the test results after 60 seconds. Then, record the leukocyte test result after an additional 60 seconds. Repeat these steps for your own urine sample, if applicable. In Activity 4, create simulated blood and filter it to produce filtrate. Then, record the initial filtrate appearance. Next, fill dialysis tubing with the filtrate and submerge the tube in uncooked rice for 1 hour. Finally, record the final filtrate appearance.

text: Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking pictures
Clear, resealable plastic bags (optional)
Timer or mobile device with a timer function
Permanent marker
Approximately 1 tsp ground coffee (not instant)
Paper towels
Ruler (optional)
Access to a toilet
Access to a sink and tap water
Piece of white paper
Spoon or stirrer

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Urinary Physiology investigation (item number 580548) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.

Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing each activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activities. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

You may wish to enclose your timing device and/or your camera or mobile device in resealable plastic bags to protect them from contamination while you work, particularly if you will be testing your own <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button>.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following structures work together to convey urine from the kidneys to the bladder and then to the exterior?
Which of the following is the functional unit of the kidney?
Through which vessel does blood leave the glomerulus?
Which of the following lists the three main nitrogenous waste products generated by the human body?
Which of the following would be considered within the normal specific gravity range for an adult human's urine?
Which of the following best describes the relationship between the solute concentration and the specific gravity value of a urine sample?

options.text: The greater the solute concentration the higher the specific gravity value.
The greater the solute concentration the lower the specific gravity value.
The solute concentration is equal to the specific gravity value.
The solute concentration is the inverse of the specific gravity value.
The solute concentration is one half the specific gravity value.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following conditions is most likely to be associated with low urine pH values?
Coffee grounds, dialysis tubing and uncooked rice are used to conduct which of the following activities in this investigation?

options.text: modeling the process of urine production
assessing the color and odor of simulated urine
determining the composition of real urine
measuring the specific gravity of simulated urine
measuring the pH of real urine

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the average pH of urine?
Which of the following best describes the structure of a glomerulus?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Review all instructions carefully before you begin.
Clear the work area.
Obtain all materials, including those needed but not supplied.
Put on your PPE: gloves, lab apron, and safety goggles.

If you will be testing your own , collect the sample while in a bathroom. The best time to collect urine is early in the morning. To collect the urine, use a clean specimen cup. Do not collect the first volume because this contains a higher concentration of microorganisms from the urethra, which will be washed away by the first volume. Insert the cup in the stream. Carefully collect the urine. When finished collecting, close the lid. If not used immediately, store the entire cup in a closed plastic bag in the refrigerator. Use only your own urine—do not obtain urine from anyone else for testing.

In Activity 1, you will measure the <button class='glossary-text'>specific gravity</button> of the two simulated <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button> samples, and optionally your own urine sample, using a <button class='glossary-text'>hydrometer</button>. If you decide to use your own urine in this activity, measure it in the hydrometer last and save the sample in the hydrometer jar for Activity 2.

pages.title: Measuring Specific Gravity Using a Hydrometer (6 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
Measuring Specific Gravity Using a Hydrometer (6 steps)

pageData.text: Place a clean paper towel on your work surface. Set the <button class='glossary-text'>hydrometer</button> jar on the paper towel.
Select one of the two simulated <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button> samples, and pour some of the sample into the jar of the hydrometer to approximately 3 cm from the top.

Hold the hydrometer by the stem (the slender portion with the <button class='glossary-text'>specific gravity</button> scale), and carefully lower it into the jar. Give it a slight, gentle spin as you release the hydrometer. It should float in the sample. Do not force the hydrometer deeper into the sample because if too much fluid adheres to the stem, the reading may be inaccurate.

Read the specific gravity scale with your eye level with the meniscus (concave surface) of the sample. Determine which line on the hydrometer intersects the lowest point of the meniscus. Record the specific gravity in Data Table 1, and take a picture of the specific gravity scale at the meniscus to document your reading.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Remove the hydrometer from the jar, rinse it thoroughly with tap water, and dry it with a paper towel. Empty the contents of the jar into a toilet. Rinse the jar thoroughly with tap water, and dry it inside and out with a paper towel.
Repeat Steps 1-5 for the other simulated urine sample and, if desired, your own urine. If you will perform Activity 2, save your own urine (real urine) sample in the hydrometer jar.

This is an optional activity in which you will evaluate the color, <button class='glossary-text'>turbidity</button>, and odor of your own <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button> sample. This sample should be what was saved in the <button class='glossary-text'>hydrometer</button> jar from Activity 1; the contents of the hydrometer jar can be discarded after this activity. Keep the remainder of your original urine sample for use in Activity 3.

pages.title: Assessing the Appearance and Odor of Real Urine (optional) (4 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
Assessing the Appearance and Odor of Real Urine (optional) (4 steps)

pageData.text: Hold the jar containing the real from Activity 1 against a piece of white paper. Determine the color, which normally varies from pale yellow to dark amber depending on concentration. Record the color in Data Table 2, and take a picture of the sample against the white paper.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Look through the urine at a piece of paper or screen with text on it (such as these instructions) to gauge its clarity. The urine may be clear, slightly turbid, or very turbid. If you can easily read the text through the sample, the sample is clear. If you cannot read the text, the sample is very turbid. If you can see the text but experience some difficulty reading it, the sample is slightly turbid. Record your observation in Data Table 2, and take a picture of the sample in front of the text.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Take the jar and hold it under your nose at about chin level. Carefully sniff the urine. It should smell only slightly. The darker the color, the stronger the odor will likely be. If the odor is very faint, record “weak” in Data Table 2. If you need to quickly remove the jar, record the odor as “strong.” If the urine has a distinct odor but is not so strong that you need to remove the jar, record the odor as “slight.”
Discard the contents of the jar into a toilet.

In Activity 3, you will use <button class='glossary-text'>urinalysis</button> test strips to determine the composition of the two simulated <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button> samples, and optionally your own urine sample.

Place two paper cups on the paper towel: label one “simulated normal” and the other “simulated unknown.” If you are also testing your own <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button>, label a third cup “real urine.”
Ensure that each cup is about ¾ full.
Remove a fresh test strip from the packet, taking care to touch only the plastic and not the raised test surfaces.
Working with one sample at a time, briefly immerse the strip in the first sample so that all test surfaces are submerged.
Remove the strip from the sample with the test surfaces facing up. Draw the opposite side of the strip across the rim of the cup to remove excess sample.

Turn the strip onto its edge (not the test surfaces), and tap it once on the paper towel to remove any remaining excess sample. Do not wipe the strip dry. Let the strip rest, test surfaces facing up, on the paper towel.
Start your timer, and after 60 seconds, compare the strip to Figure 2 and Table 1. Take a photo of the strip and record your results quickly in Data Table 3.

Continue timing for an additional 60 seconds (120 seconds total). Compare the strip to Figure 2 and Table 1 with respect to the test surface. If there has been a change since the 60-second reading, record the results in Data Table 3.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.desc: Figure 2: PH color strip chart, showing colors as listed in Table 1 to compare at 60 seconds for PH, glucose, ketones, leukocytes, nitrite, protein, and blood/hemoglobin: and at 120 seconds for leukocytes
pageData.altText: Figure 2: PH color strip chart, showing colors as listed in Table 1 to compare at 60 seconds for PH, glucose, ketones, leukocytes, nitrite, protein, and blood/hemoglobin: and at 120 seconds for leukocytes

header.text: Interpretation Guide for Urinalysis Test Strips

tableData.text: Very dense collection of green dots

* Blue-green and dark blue-green can be challenging to distinguish from one another.
** If intact erythrocytes are present, they will appear as green dots on a yellow background. A uniform green background indicates free hemoglobin from hemolyzed erythrocytes and/or myoglobin.
tableData.hoverText:
* Blue-green and dark blue-green can be challenging to distinguish from one another.
** If intact erythrocytes are present, they will appear as green dots on a yellow background. A uniform green background indicates free hemoglobin from hemolyzed erythrocytes and/or myoglobin.

pageData.text: Repeat the procedure for the other samples, using a fresh test strip for each.
Dispose of the samples in the toilet.

In Activity 4 you will model the two parts of <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button> production: <button class='glossary-text'>filtration</button> and <button class='glossary-text'>reabsorption</button>. In the filtration phase, you will create a mixture of water, food coloring and coffee grounds to simulate blood; this mixture will be filtered, and the <button class='glossary-text'>filtrate</button> observed. In the reabsorption phase, you will fill a piece of dialysis tubing with the filtrate and use uncooked rice to simulate the reabsorption of water by the <button class='glossary-text'>kidneys</button> and the production of urine.
Fill a specimen cup half full of tap water, and mix in 8 drops of food coloring.
Mix in approximately 1 tsp of ground coffee. If you don’t have a teaspoon, this amount of coffee will make a small heap about the diameter of a quarter in the palm of your hand.
Place the filter paper over the opening of a different specimen cup, fold the paper over the rim, and secure it with a rubber band.
Slowly pour the mixture onto the filter. This step should be performed in a sink in case of spills.
Remove the filter paper, and take a picture of the <button class='glossary-text'>filtrate</button>.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Fill a clean plastic specimen cup with tap water.
Submerge one piece of dialysis tubing in the water for at least 30 seconds, and then remove it. Pour out the water, dry the cup with a paper towel, and save the cup for Step 10.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Gently roll the end of the tubing between your index finger and thumb. This should cause the dialysis tubing to open. Continue rolling the tubing down its length until the tubing is completely open.
Seal one end of the tubing by twisting 2-3 cm of the tubing and tying a simple knot (see Figure 3). This knot should be as close to the end as possible.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: A simple knot tied on one end of a piece of dialysis tubing
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A simple knot tied on one end of a piece of dialysis tubing

pageData.text: Use a pipet to fill the tubing approximately half full with filtrate.

Carefully remove most of the air from the space above the solution, leaving only a small bubble. To expel air, gently squeeze the tubing upward with the thumb and index finger of one hand while supporting the filled tubing with the other hand.
Seal off the open end of the tubing by twisting 2-3 cm and tying a simple knot at the end (see Figure 3). This knot should be as close to the end as possible.
Dry the dialysis tubing by blotting it with a clean paper towel.
Take a picture of the tubing, and record your observations about the volume and color of the sample in Data Table 4.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Cover the bottom of the plastic specimen cup with rice.
Place the filled dialysis tubing in the cup. You may need to bend the tubing to make it fit.
Cover the tubing with more rice.
Let the tubing sit in the rice for at least one hour. (There is no need to put the lid on the cup.)
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Remove the tubing from the rice, and take a picture to compare to your previous photo. Record your observations of the change in the volume and color of the sample in Data Table 4.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

text: Dispose of <button class='glossary-text'>urine</button> samples (simulated and real) in the toilet.
Used gloves, used and unused dialysis tubing, filter paper, rubber bands, paper cups, rice, plastic cups and lids, used test strips, pipets, and paper towels may be discarded in household garbage.
Rinse the and jar with tap water, dry them with a paper towel or allow them to air-dry, and store them with the rest of your lab kit.
Clean the work surface with soap and water.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

text: What is the significance of the specific gravity of the abnormal urine?

pageData.title: Questions
text: What is represented by the coffee in Activity 4?
What is simulated by the placing the dialysis tubing in rice?

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagrams of the kidney showing its major structures and the nephron, depicting its major structures and the direction of blood flow
pageData.content: Figure 1. The parts of a kidney and nephron

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for this investigation. As an optional preparation, you can collect your own urine sample. In Activity 1, you will measure the specific gravity of both simulated urine samples using the hydrometer. Repeat this step for your own urine sample, if applicable. Activity 2 is only for those testing their own urine. You will determine the color, clarity, and odor strength of your own urine. In Activity 3, you will test both simulated urine samples with urinalysis test strips and record the test results after 60 seconds. Then, record the leukocyte test result after an additional 60 seconds. Repeat these steps for your own urine sample, if applicable. In Activity 4, create simulated blood and filter it to produce filtrate. Then, record the initial filtrate appearance. Next, fill dialysis tubing with the filtrate and submerge the tube in uncooked rice for 1 hour. Finally, record the final filtrate appearance.

Figure 2: PH color strip chart, showing colors as listed in Table 1 to compare at 60 seconds for PH, glucose, ketones, leukocytes, nitrite, protein, and blood/hemoglobin: and at 120 seconds for leukocytes

pageData.content: Table 1. Interpretation guide for urinalysis test strips
pageData.title: Table 1.

header.text: Interpretation Guide for Urinalysis Test Strips

tableData.text: Very dense collection of green dots

* Blue-green and dark blue-green can be challenging to distinguish from one another.
** If intact erythrocytes are present, they will appear as green dots on a yellow background. A uniform green background indicates free hemoglobin from hemolyzed erythrocytes and/or myoglobin.
tableData.hoverText:
* Blue-green and dark blue-green can be challenging to distinguish from one another.
** If intact erythrocytes are present, they will appear as green dots on a yellow background. A uniform green background indicates free hemoglobin from hemolyzed erythrocytes and/or myoglobin.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: A simple knot tied on one end of a piece of dialysis tubing
pageData.content: Figure 3. The knotted end of a dialysis tube

data.title: Afferent arteriole
data.content: Feeds blood into the glomerulus

data.title: Ascending limb
data.content: Where the nephron loop reenters the cortex

data.title: Collecting duct
data.content: Collects urine from the nephrons

data.title: Cortex
data.content: Outer layer of the kidney, contains the blood-filtering structures

data.title: Creatinine
data.content: Released when creatine phosphate is used in skeletal muscle

data.title: Descending limb
data.content: Loops from the cortex into the medulla of the kidney, are permeable to water but not to urea or ions

data.title: Diabetes insipidus
data.content: Occurs when the kidneys are unable to concentrate the urine due to either an ADH deficiency or to an inability of the kidneys to respond to this hormone.

data.title: Diabetes mellitus
data.content: A disorder in which blood levels of glucose become so high that the glucose cannot all be reabsorbed and the excess ends up in the urine

data.title: Distal convoluted tubule
data.content: Lies between the loop of Henle and the nonsecretory part of the nephron, solute concentrations are adjusted

data.title: Efferent arteriole
data.content: "Outgoing", carries blood away from the glomerulus

data.title: Filtrate
data.content: A solution of water and solutes that is filtered from the blood

data.title: Filtration
data.content: The process of water and solutes being filtered from the blood to yield a fluid called filtrate

data.title: Glomerular capsule
data.content: Filtration structure that is part of the glomerulus; also called Bowman's capsule

data.title: Glomerulus
data.content: One of two structures that make up a nephron, capillary network around the nephron,  waste products are filtered from the blood

data.title: Glycosuria
data.content: Glucose in the urine

data.title: Gout
data.content: Condition identified by high levels of uric acid crystals in the urine, may cause sudden onset of pain and swelling in the joints, particularly the base of the big toe

data.title: Hematuria
data.content: Urine that is pink or red, may indicate potentially serious disorders of the blood and/or urinary system

data.title: Hydrometer
data.content: A simple device to measure specific gravity

data.title: Insulin
data.content: A hormone produced in the pancreas that regulates the amount of glucose in the blood

data.title: Kidneys
data.content: Two bean-shaped organs are responsible for the three processes involved in urine production

data.title: Kidney stones
data.content: Renal calculi, are solid masses of crystals that may be detected in kidneys, ureters, or the bladder

data.title: Leukocyte
data.content: White blood cells (WBC) part of the body's immune system

data.title: Loop of the nephron (loop of Henle)
data.content: The hairpin turn in the descending limb of the nephron that reverses its orientation; also called the loop of Henle

data.title: Medulla
data.content: Inner layer of the kidney, contains the structures responsible for maintaining the solute-water balance of the blood

data.title: Nephron
data.content: The functional unit of the kidney

data.title: Osmoregulation
data.content: The control of solutes, mostly ions, in blood and other body fluids

data.title: Peritubular capillaries
data.content: Capillaries surrounding the renal tubule

data.title: Proteinuria
data.content: Excess protein in the urine

data.title: Proximal convoluted tubule
data.content: The first segment of the renal tubule

data.title: Reabsorption
data.content: Water and solutes are returned to the blood, and filtrate becomes urine

data.title: Renal corpuscle
data.content: The glomerulus and its capsule

data.title: Renal tubule
data.content: One of two structures that make up a nephron,  tiny tubes in the kidneys that returns nutrients, fluids, and other substances that have been filtered from the blood

data.title: Secretion
data.content: Substances are removed from the blood

data.title: Specific gravity
data.content: A gauge of how concentrated or dilute a urine sample is

data.title: Turbidity
data.content: Urine that is cloudy, may suggest a urinary tract infection (UTI)

data.title: Urea
data.content: The main nitrogenous waste in the urine of humans and other mammals

data.title: Uric acid
data.content: Produced when purines, a key component of nucleic acids, are degraded

data.title: Urinalysis
data.content: Analysis of urine

data.title: Urine
data.content: The fluid formed by the kidneys, is 95% water and 5% solutes, including nitrogenous wastes
